awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Societal Collapse and Migration
awd_abstract_narration:
Jose Raul Ortiz, a Ph.D. candidate at the University of Arizona, will investigate how Maya highland communities were affected by potential immigration after the abandonment of lowland centers during the 9-10th centuries. Recent research on the Terminal Classic in the Maya area shows that Maya communities were differentially affected by collapse processes and their responses were variable, including cases of disruption and abandonment, short flourishment, and resilience and transformation. Ortiz's research will focus on the detection of migration from a potential receiving end, a theme that has been addressed in other worldwide ancient migration cases but that has been minimally tracked in other Maya sub-regions. Questions about the effects of the Maya collapse, including the impact of lowland population movements, have been less frequently addressed for the highlands. The results of this research will contribute to the growing discussion on how social identity, specifically of the ancient Maya, intersects with technology, and how migrants can be detected in the archaeological record. Ortiz's work seeks to make a positive impact on the indigenous Qeqchi Maya living near the site by providing important culture-historical information from their own cultural past and promoting collaborative participation, re-ownership, and safekeeping of local cultural heritage. The results of the project seek to publicly discuss the myriad ways that Maya communities experienced the Maya collapse by contesting popular and catastrophic beliefs of this social process.

Under the direction of Dr. Takeshi Inomata, Mr. Ortiz will conduct archaeological research at Kixpek, Guatemala. This ancient settlement is located at the northern edge of the highlands immediately south of the lowlands region. Funerary pottery found at the site indicates a Late Classic to Early Postclassic occupation (AD 600-1200), showing that the community lived through the Classic Maya collapse. The site of Kixpek on the Chixoy drainage presents an opportunity to examine how a highland community experienced social processes that happened during and after the Terminal Classic. Did migrants relocate among their neighbors at the northern highlands and what evidence of this migration is available at this region? Did highland ceramic technologies persist or change with the potential introduction of new social groups after the Maya collapse? Ortiz will conduct excavations in Group B and presumed habitation areas surrounding the main plaza in order to obtain pottery samples from pre- and post-Maya collapse periods of occupation. Laboratory analysis will include detailed ceramic analysis by stylistic and technological attributes through macroscopic and microscopic techniques for pottery classification. Ortiz will evaluate the continuities and changes in technological systems, specifically in pottery, obsidian, and burial practices at Kixpek, amidst the potential relocation of people after the Terminal Classic period.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The collapse of ancient societies is a popular topic among researchers and general audiences providing an entry point into how groups deal with social and environmental challenges. Studying cross-cultural and cross-time examples can also provide insight regarding small and large-scale disruptions in today's world. The Lowland Maya collapse (circa AD 750-1000) has received special attention from scholars and systematic research has examined the causes, breadth, and consequences of this process. One of the main features of this occurrence is the abandonment of multiple centers across the southern Lowlands which posed variable reactions in many other sub-regions of the Maya area including the highlands. Research carried out at Kixpek, Guatemala, addressed whether migrants of the Lowland 9-10th century collapse relocated to the edge of the northern highlands and how changes in trade routes, new pan-regional styles, and political disruption affected and transformed local technological systems.

  Kixpek was a small Maya settlement in the lower Chixoy in the vicinity of Uspantan, Guatemala. Previous research from the 1920s suggested an occupation for the Classic to Postclassic transition. Our excavations at Kixpek revealed that Group B, a plaza arrangement of five buildings and a ballcourt, functioned as the center of ritual activity between AD 750 and 1050. Ceramic chronological markers and radiocarbon dating confirm the occupation at Group B to the end of the Late Classic and Early Postclassic periods. Excavations conducted in Groups B and C and outlying areas and the artifacts recovered therein provide significant data about the ceramic and lithic technologies in a challenging context in Maya history.

  During the Late Classic (Chama 4 ceramic complex, AD 750-830), Kixpek inhabitants consumed a collection of vessels including jars, bowls, and cylinders with different color slips. Among the most common utilitarian vessels are so-called highland style wares (red, brown-black, red-orange; red-on-buff, and orange-on-cream) but also Transversal/Lowland wares (unslipped calcite-tempered and bowls with ridge). During this period, Group B was constructed, enlarged, and became the place for public ritual events and burials of a few local elites. At the end of the Classic period (Chipal 1 complex, AD 830-900), a few orange fine paste vessels were introduced from the Western Lowlands via the Chixoy-Salinas-Usumacinta route and green obsidian from Central Mexico. Around AD 900 (Chipal 2 complex), Tohil Plumbate pottery appeared at Kixpek along with a few new red-slipped types. Late Classic pottery including volcanic and calcite paste preferences persisted but there was an increase in the use of grog as temper. Only a few structures in Group B had minor renovations. Others were in the process of being remodeled but were left unfinished.

  Preliminary evidence at Kixpek does not show significant post-900 AD disruptive processes that can be attributed to elite migrants as mentioned for sites up the Chixoy River. We do notice, however, a decline in the quality of ceramic vessels and building materials in the Early Postclassic (AD 900-1200s) that could be associated with the broader dynamics of the Lowland Maya collapse. This decaying quality in pottery and architecture could indicate a decrease in population. This potentially occurred in tandem or as a reaction to the AD 1000 desertion of settlements to the north along the Transversal strip, a region with whom Kixpek had close relations indicated by ceramic and lithic data. Lower Chixoy sites had the same fate a few decades later and Kixpek could have been abandoned circa AD 1050.

  This research also provided a new way for Q'eqchi'-Maya of the modern community Saquixpec to reconnect with local heritage and preserve local Maya cultural values through learning about the former inhabitants of these ancestral localities. This project contests the popular belief that Maya communities ended after the Maya sociopolitical collapse and instead shows how multiple communities from different Maya cultural expressions interacted, persisted, and changed through time. The results from the project have been disseminated through informal talks among the local community and three symposium presentations in Spanish and English, two of which will be published. Other publications, conferences, and a dissertation are in preparation. Moreover, the project has collaborated with Universidad del Valle in training Guatemalan undergraduate students and with Cementos Progreso in combined efforts from the academic and private sectors to advance scientific and social science research in Guatemala.
